message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the physical properties of substances and phase changes. Lemonade is made up of water and lemon juice, so when it is heated, the water component can evaporate and form steam. Option (A) is incorrect because heating lemonade will not form water, as it already contains water. Option (B) is incorrect because cooling lemonade will not form steam, as steam is a gas and cooling a liquid will not cause it to turn into a gas. Option (D) is incorrect because steam is a gas and cannot be cooled to form itself.

This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of matter and phase changes. Lemonade is a mixture of water and lemon juice, so when it is heated, the water in the lemonade can evaporate and form steam. Option (A) is incorrect because heating lemonade does not form pure water, only the water component of the lemonade can change phase. Option (B) is incorrect because cooling lemonade would not result in the formation of steam. Option (D) is incorrect because steam is formed by heating water, not by cooling it.

To answer this question, we need some basic knowledge of the states of matter and the properties of lemonade and water. Lemonade is a mixture of water, lemon juice, and sugar. When lemonade is heated, the water component will evaporate and form steam. This means that lemonade can be heated to form steam. Option (A) is incorrect because heating lemonade will not form pure water, but rather water vapor along with other components of lemonade. Option (B) is also incorrect because cooling lemonade will not form steam, but rather it will form a liquid state. Option (D) is incorrect because water does not need to be cooled to form steam, it needs to be heated instead.

This question requires basic knowledge of the phases of matter and the process of heating and cooling. When lemonade is heated, it can be turned into steam, as the heat causes the water in the lemonade to evaporate. Option (A) is incorrect because heating lemonade will not form water, as lemonade already contains water as one of its main components. Option (B) is also incorrect because cooling lemonade will not form steam, as steam is the gaseous phase of water and cooling will cause the lemonade to condense into liquid form. Option (D) is also incorrect because cooling water will not form steam, it will form ice as it transitions from a liquid to a solid state.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of matter and the changes that occur with temperature. When lemonade is heated, the water in the lemonade can evaporate and form steam. Option (A) is incorrect because heating lemonade does not form water (though water is a component of lemonade). Option (B) is incorrect because cooling lemonade does not form steam. Option (D) is also incorrect because cooling water does not form steam.

This question requires knowledge about the phase changes of water. When lemonade is heated, it can be transformed into steam, which is the gaseous form of water. Option (A) is incorrect because lemonade is already a mixture of water and lemon juice, so heating it would not "form" water. Option (B) is incorrect because cooling lemonade would not result in the formation of steam. Option (D) is incorrect because cooling water would not form steam, but rather it would form ice when its temperature drops below its freezing point.
